channel.title: RsBuddy is hacking
channel.description:
3 of my irl friends use Rsbuddy (none live together), and all of their accounts have been hacked. Just watch what scripts you guys use, and if its not widely used don't use it. Unlike Rsbot when you'd add scripts manually, this is a lot more sketchy. I wouldn't trust it.
http://rsbuddy.com/forum/search.php?searchid=789558

item.title: RsBuddy is hacking
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

[quote=“T4_, post:38, topic:399027”][quote author=Davidi2 link=topic=496162.msg3632270#msg3632270 date=1308332847]
And I wouldn’t doubt that some day some kid is going to get greedy, and make a paid bot that also steals your password.
[/quote]
Are the developers of RSBuddy children?[/quote]Who said anything about RSBuddy? I’m talking about all the paid bots people are worshiping

Read full topic

item.title: RsBuddy is hacking
item.dc:creator: @m.dog311 m.dog311
item.description:
@m.dog311 wrote:

[quote=“DevilsCape, post:35, topic:399027”]Dont Trust any Bot that is free >>

u have to pay 25$ or so … for real safe working pro bots …

i wanted a free one for money and i made a thread but everyone is sh!t these days … they say bad comments … w8ever[/quote]
There are plenty of free bots that are good. RSBuddy, Simba, SCAR isn’t the greatest (especially compared to Simba), but it still works.

Read full topic

item.title: RsBuddy is hacking
item.dc:creator: @m.dog311 m.dog311
item.description:
@m.dog311 wrote:

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:31, topic:399027”][quote author=m.dog311 link=topic=496162.msg3630387#msg3630387 date=1308168713]

Scripts are examined before being accepted, any code that could be malicious is flagged and then examined individually. IF it was in fact RSBuddy, you’ll need to figure out which script(s) your three friends have been using in common, and then report them so it can be taken care of and prevented from happening again. However, I’m on the RSBuddy IRC almost constantly and there have been no other reports, so I think it’s something else.

What about updates for certain scripts, I’m sure a person like Jacmob just glances over the scripts quickly.

Iirc, he has a script that scans all submitted scripts, and checks for anything potentially malicious (accessing files, connecting to websites, etc), and then he examines anything that has been flagged. I’m sure that if he isn’t the only person checking scripts, its all handled by top members of the community (admins/developers).

[/quote]

Sounds like an awful way to do it, the right way would be to run scripts inside a SecurityManager with restricted permissions, the same way I run clients inside of MoparScape 4, then no matter what the code wants to do, it will only be allowed to do things you want.[/quote]
They would do that, but as Davidi said, they want certain scripts to be able to do things like that (scripts you have to pay for, trusted scripts that want to collect usage data, etc).

Read full topic

item.title: RsBuddy is hacking
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:31, topic:399027”][quote author=m.dog311 link=topic=496162.msg3630387#msg3630387 date=1308168713]

Scripts are examined before being accepted, any code that could be malicious is flagged and then examined individually. IF it was in fact RSBuddy, you’ll need to figure out which script(s) your three friends have been using in common, and then report them so it can be taken care of and prevented from happening again. However, I’m on the RSBuddy IRC almost constantly and there have been no other reports, so I think it’s something else.

What about updates for certain scripts, I’m sure a person like Jacmob just glances over the scripts quickly.

Iirc, he has a script that scans all submitted scripts, and checks for anything potentially malicious (accessing files, connecting to websites, etc), and then he examines anything that has been flagged. I’m sure that if he isn’t the only person checking scripts, its all handled by top members of the community (admins/developers).

[/quote]

Sounds like an awful way to do it, the right way would be to run scripts inside a SecurityManager with restricted permissions, the same way I run clients inside of MoparScape 4, then no matter what the code wants to do, it will only be allowed to do things you want.[/quote]That’s what I talked to Jacmob about as well, and he said that they do it so that certain scripts can still use certain permissions that would normally be blocked, as long as it couldn’t be used for malicious purposes. So in other words, they don’t block people using Account.getPassword() or other things that could be malicious, they check to see how that code is used and if there would be a possibility of it being used maliciously.

Read full topic

item.title: RsBuddy is hacking
item.dc:creator: @T41 t4
item.description:
@T41 wrote:

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:31, topic:399027”][quote author=m.dog311 link=topic=496162.msg3630387#msg3630387 date=1308168713]

Scripts are examined before being accepted, any code that could be malicious is flagged and then examined individually. IF it was in fact RSBuddy, you’ll need to figure out which script(s) your three friends have been using in common, and then report them so it can be taken care of and prevented from happening again. However, I’m on the RSBuddy IRC almost constantly and there have been no other reports, so I think it’s something else.

What about updates for certain scripts, I’m sure a person like Jacmob just glances over the scripts quickly.

Iirc, he has a script that scans all submitted scripts, and checks for anything potentially malicious (accessing files, connecting to websites, etc), and then he examines anything that has been flagged. I’m sure that if he isn’t the only person checking scripts, its all handled by top members of the community (admins/developers).

[/quote]

Sounds like an awful way to do it, the right way would be to run scripts inside a SecurityManager with restricted permissions, the same way I run clients inside of MoparScape 4, then no matter what the code wants to do, it will only be allowed to do things you want.[/quote]
Either way, they have steps in place to prevent malicious code (which ultimately would most likely steal Runescape credentials). And you must remember, the individuals who make the scripts are either kids or older individuals looking to make a few dollars (or thousands in iDung’s case).

Read full topic

item.title: RsBuddy is hacking
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

[quote=“m.dog311, post:30, topic:399027”][quote author=the elve age link=topic=496162.msg3627737#msg3627737 date=1307975744]

Scripts are examined before being accepted, any code that could be malicious is flagged and then examined individually. IF it was in fact RSBuddy, you’ll need to figure out which script(s) your three friends have been using in common, and then report them so it can be taken care of and prevented from happening again. However, I’m on the RSBuddy IRC almost constantly and there have been no other reports, so I think it’s something else.

What about updates for certain scripts, I’m sure a person like Jacmob just glances over the scripts quickly.
[/quote]
Iirc, he has a script that scans all submitted scripts, and checks for anything potentially malicious (accessing files, connecting to websites, etc), and then he examines anything that has been flagged. I’m sure that if he isn’t the only person checking scripts, its all handled by top members of the community (admins/developers).[/quote]

Sounds like an awful way to do it, the right way would be to run scripts inside a SecurityManager with restricted permissions, the same way I run clients inside of MoparScape 4, then no matter what the code wants to do, it will only be allowed to do things you want.

Read full topic

item.title: RsBuddy is hacking
item.dc:creator: @Marine5287 Marine5287
item.description:
@Marine5287 wrote:

[quote=“Newty, post:19, topic:399027”]I think all scripts are looked over and approved by Jacmob. From what I hear Jacmob is just like MITB when it comes to his outlook on scamming, etc (to bad he isn’t an opensource fanboy too!).

Back to the point; if Jacmob approved it then I doubt there is any malicious code.[/quote]

I agree. I’ve been using RSBuddy for a year now and I’ve got so much 99’s from it without getting hacked or banned amazingly.

Although when I first started botting with PowerBot I did get hacked.

Read full topic

item.title: RsBuddy is hacking
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

[quote=“the elve age, post:22, topic:399027”][quote author=Davidi2 link=topic=496162.msg3627515#msg3627515 date=1307942408]
Scripts are examined before being accepted, any code that could be malicious is flagged and then examined individually. IF it was in fact RSBuddy, you’ll need to figure out which script(s) your three friends have been using in common, and then report them so it can be taken care of and prevented from happening again. However, I’m on the RSBuddy IRC almost constantly and there have been no other reports, so I think it’s something else.
[/quote]
What about updates for certain scripts, I’m sure a person like Jacmob just glances over the scripts quickly.[/quote]That would also be flagged, and isn’t allowed. And it isn’t Jacmob that does it, it’s someone called NoEffex, whose entire job is just approving scripts.

Read full topic

item.title: RsBuddy is hacking
item.dc:creator: @Jrekko Jrekko
item.description:
@Jrekko wrote:

Your friends have no idea if it’s RSBuddy or not. Most of the people from powerbot/rsbuddy are unaware of things like phishers/keyloggers and when they are hacked, they instantly blame the bot or the scripts, because they don’t actually know what just happened to them.

Read full topic

However, I’m on the RSBuddy IRC almost constantly and there have been no other reports, so I think it’s something else.

item.title: RsBuddy is hacking
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

Andrew Ferguson:

Just don’t save your real account information on the applet. Simple as that, they can’t steal your password unless you enter it into their applet.

That’s entirely false. They can do many different things to steal your password, even if you don’t ‘enter it into their applet’. Some right off the top of my head would be to use reflection to grab the password right out of the runescape client, or install a keylogger to steal your password.

Read full topic

Back to the point; if Jacmob approved it then I doubt there is any malicious code.
